channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Italy, Bracing for Electoral Season of Fake News, Demands Facebook’s Help
item.media:description: Supporters of the Five Star Movement at a rally in Catania, Italy, last month. The Five Star Movement has hosted on its associated websites anti-Renzi propaganda originating on Russian outlets.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: As a crucial election nears, leaders like Matteo Renzi are on high alert for fake news and foreign meddling.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Can Keir Starmer Save Britain From Brexit?
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the Labour Party’s point man on Brexit, speaking at the party conference in September. Some say he is trying to draw out the process, hoping the public will turn decisively against it.
item.description: Labour’s point man on Brexit policy has subtly shifted the party’s strategy on leaving the E.U. Can he go further and change the country’s course, too?
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Oxford Circus Station in London Reopens After Panicked Evacuation
item.media:description: An armed police officer running down Oxford Street, a busy shopping street in central London, on Friday.
item.description: The police said they received reports of gunfire, and responded as if to a terrorist incident, but found no sign of shooting. The station has reopened.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE and KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Zimbabwe’s New Leader Stirs Fears That He Resembles the Old One
item.media:description: Emmerson Mnangagwa, center right, and his wife, Auxillia, arriving at the presidential inauguration ceremony in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Friday.
item.description: Former Vice President Emmerson Mnangagwa succeeded the leader he helped to topple, Robert Mugabe, who had held the office since independence 37 years ago.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI and JEFFREY MOYO

item.title: Oscar Pistorius’s Murder Sentence Is Increased to 15 Years
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius leaving the High Court in Pretoria, South Africa, in 2016.
item.description: South African prosecutors had said the six-year sentence that the sprinter received for killing his girlfriend in 2013 was “shockingly lenient.”
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Serbia’s Brand of Reconciliation: Embracing Old War Criminals
item.media:description: A man holding a “Ratko Mladic Boulevard” placard during a gathering in Belgrade, Serbia, on Wednesday in support of the Bosnian Serb general convicted of war crimes.
item.description: Despite the conviction of Gen. Ratko Mladic for war crimes, Serbia’s collective memory of its role in the Yugoslav civil wars is more forgiving.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW BRUNWASSER
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: Hopes Dashed, Relatives of Argentine Submarine Crew Turn to Grief and Anger
item.media:description: Members of the Argentine Air Force searching for the missing submarine in the South Atlantic on Tuesday.
item.description: Disclosure of an explosion near the San Juan raised fears that its 44-member crew had been lost, though the search continued.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL POLITI and ERNESTO LONDOÑO

item.title: Why Putin’s Foes Deplore U.S. Fixation on Election Meddling
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin, left, with Prime Minister Dmitry Medvedev. Critics says the American focus on Moscow’s election meddling has helped reinforce Mr. Putin’s portrayal as a geopolitical genius in the Russian state news media.
item.description: “Enough already!” one critic of President Vladimir V. Putin said, worried that the accusations were helping the Kremlin polish the president’s image as a master strategist.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: An American Spy Base Hidden in Australia’s Outback
item.media:description: The Joint Defense Facility Pine Gap, photographed in 2014. Born at the height of the Cold War, the base near the town of Alice Springs was originally presented to the Australian public as a space research facility.
item.description: The trials of six Christian antiwar protesters have put a spotlight on a facility that the United States would rather keep in the shadows.
item.dc:creator: JACKIE DENT

item.title: The Land of Apology and a Return to Montreal: The Canada Letter
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau in the House of Commons, where he will present an apology for a program that drove gays and lesbians out of the government and military.
item.description: This week’s newsletter about Canada and for Canadians looks into Canadians’ tendency to say sorry and welcomes an expat home.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Egypt, Michael Flynn, Argentina: Your Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: PENN BULLOCK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Who Are Sufi Muslims and Why Do Some Extremists Hate Them?
item.media:description: Muslims praying at the shrine of a Sufi saint on Wednesday in Srinagar, Kashmir.
item.description: A terrorist attack in Egypt has focused attention on the mystical school of Islam, which emphasizes the inward search for divinity.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Trudeau Apologizes for Abuse and ‘Profound Cultural Loss’ at Indigenous Schools
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau with Toby Obed, a former student and a leader of a lawsuit that led up to the apology.
item.media:credit: Andrew Vaughan/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: The Canadian premier said former students of boarding schools in Newfoundland and Labrador “face adversity today” because of their schooling.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Russia Is Returning to Growth. (Just in Time for an Election.)
item.media:description: Oil tanks in the town of Nakhodka, Russia. Higher oil prices have helped the country’s economy.
item.description: Russia’s economy is finally emerging from a difficult recession, just as President Vladimir V. Putin gears up for a presidential election.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Scene of Deadly Attack at Egypt Mosque
item.description: At least 235 people were killed when militants detonated explosives and sprayed gunfire at a crowded Sufi mosque near Egypt’s Sinai coast.

item.title: Crimean Tatar Activist Dies After Search by Russian Agents
item.media:description: President Petro Poroshenko, left, of Ukraine met with the president of the European Council, Donald Tusk, in Brussels on Thursday. Mr. Poroshenko said the death of Vedzhie Kashka showed that “the only form of protection for the Crimean Tatar people is the liberation of Crimea from occupation” by Russia.
item.description: Vedzhie Kashka, 83, “a legendary woman of the Crimean Tatar national movement” who once worked with Andrei Sakharov, was buried on Friday.
item.dc:creator: SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

item.title: Ireland Edges Toward Snap Election as Government Teeters
item.media:description: Prime Minister Leo Varadkar speaking at his party’s conference in Ballyconnell, Ireland, this month.
item.description: A motion of no-confidence in the deputy prime minister, filed by the main opposition party, could end a fragile coalition just as Dublin wrestles with Brexit talks.
item.dc:creator: ED O’LOUGHLIN and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Consensus? No, Thanks. German Politics Suddenly Get Messy.
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany departing after a day of coalition talks in Berlin this month. The Sept. 24 election returned a difficult result, reflecting the country’s increasing polarization.
item.description: The breakdown of coalition talks may signal the end of the country’s postwar tradition of compromise. Not everyone thinks that’s a bad thing.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY and KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Militants Kill 235 at Sufi Mosque in Egypt’s Deadliest Terrorist Attack
item.media:description: Most worshipers at the mosque were Sufi Muslims, who practice a mystical form of Islam that some extremists consider heretical.
item.description: The assault, in an area racked by an Islamist insurgency, sent shock waves across the nation — not only for the death toll but also for the choice of target.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH and NOUR YOUSSEF

item.title: Beijing Kindergarten Is Accused of Abuse, and Internet Erupts in Fury
item.media:description: A crowd gathered Friday outside the gates of RYB Kindergarten in Xintiandi, in eastern Beijing. Anger over allegations of mistreatment has laid bare the distrust that many Chinese feel about schools and their accountability.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Parents claim children were fed pills, jabbed and stripped. While the police have released no conclusions, public ire shows broad anxiety about kindergartens.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and KAROLINE KAN

item.title: Where It’s Made: Parmesan Cheese
item.description: Visit a parmesan dairy in northern Italy, where Parmigiano-Reggiano originates and learn how the cheese is made.

item.title: Mitsubishi Materials Adds to Japan Inc.’s Quality Problems
item.media:description: Mitsubishi Materials’ president, Akira Takeuchi, second from right, bowing with colleagues during a news conference in Tokyo on Friday.
item.description: The supplier of parts for aircraft and autos has become the latest major Japanese company to admit to falsifying inspection data for its products.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: With Asylum Seekers Cleared From Manus Island, New Phase Begins
item.media:description: Asylum seekers at the closed Australian-run immigration detention center on Manus Island in Papua New Guinea on Thursday.
item.description: The Papua New Guinea authorities emptied a detention center Friday, moving hundreds of holdouts to facilities that the men said were not ready.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees

item.title: Mugabe Will Continue Living in Zimbabwe, Spokesman Says
item.media:description: Robert Mugabe, center, meeting last week with Zimbabwe’s military and security chiefs. He resigned as president on Tuesday following a military intervention.
item.media:credit: The Herald, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: The issue of immunity did not come up in talks with the military over the future of the former president and his wife, Grace, the spokesman said.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Rwanda Offers to Host African Migrants Stranded in Libya
item.media:description: Migrants in Tripoli, Libya, this month after they were rescued by the Libyan Navy. Many Africans enter the country seeking passage to Italy in vessels operated by smugglers.
item.description: The gesture could partly reverse the northward odyssey of African migrants seeking new lives in Europe.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Zadar Journal: Can a Wild Daisy Rejuvenate Croatia’s Farming Economy?
item.media:description: Farmhands picking curry plants by hand, sometimes harvesting acres of land with small sickles or pruning shears.
item.media:credit: Zoran Marinovic for The New York Times
item.description: Cosmetics manufacturers use an extract from a proliferating plant on the Adriatic coast in high-end creams. But so far local farmers have been unable to benefit financially.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH OROVIC

item.title: Deal on Rohingya Repatriation Inches Forward, but Hurdles Remain
item.media:description: Rohingya refugees preparing an evening meal in the Kutupalong camp in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: An announcement by Myanmar and Bangladesh brings a vague commitment to return migrants who fled death and destruction in a military crackdown.
item.dc:creator: HANNAH BEECH
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: A Radiation Cloud, and a Mystery, From Russia
item.media:description: A sign warning foreign citizens not to enter the town of Ozersk, in the Chelyabinsk region of Russia. The Mayak nuclear reprocessing plant is nearby.
item.description: The release of a nuclear isotope traced to an area in the Ural Mountains was harmless, but Moscow’s reluctance to release data has spurred fears of future cover-ups.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: China Busts a $3 Billion Underground Bank as It Tightens Its Grip on Money
item.media:description: China has strict currency restrictions that set a $50,000 limit on the money its citizens can move out of the country in a year.
item.description: The police detained seven people thought to have helped thousands of Chinese circumvent government limits on how much money they can move from the country.
item.dc:creator: SUI-LEE WEE

item.title: U.S. Navy Ends Search for 3 Sailors Missing Since Plane Crash Near Japan
item.media:description: A C-2A Greyhound propeller cargo plane launching from the aircraft carrier Ronald Reagan in the Philippine Sea. A plane of the same model crashed Wednesday on its way to the carrier.
item.description: “Our thoughts and prayers are with our lost shipmates and their families,” Rear Adm. Marc Dalton said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Militant Leader Hafiz Saeed Is Released by Pakistani Court
item.media:description: Hafiz Muhammad Saeed greeted supporters Wednesday after he was released from house arrest by a court in Lahore, Pakistan.
item.description: After months of house arrest, Mr. Saeed, who is accused in the 2008 Mumbai terrorist attacks and has a huge U.S. bounty on him, will be freer to move into politics.
item.dc:creator: MEHREEN ZAHRA-MALIK

item.title: Papua New Guinea’s Police Storm Manus Island Refugee Camp
item.media:description: In a photograph released by an Australian activist group, an asylum seeker appeared to have collapsed as Papua New Guinea police officers stormed a detention center on Manus Island on Thursday.
item.description: The authorities confronted hundreds of asylum seekers, destroying their possessions and demanding they leave for alternate facilities.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE and ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Why It’s Hard to Get Strongmen to Step Down
item.media:description: Robert Mugabe in 2008
item.description: What comes next for Robert Mugabe? The experiences of other authoritarian leaders might give him pause.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Escape From North Korea: What the Video Shows
item.description: Footage of a dramatic escape by a North Korean soldier into South Korea shows that a pursuing soldier from the North may have violated an international treaty.

item.title: Politics Shadow Arrests of Citgo Executives in Venezuela Graft Inquiry
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro in Caracas this week. The arrests of several Citgo executives were seen by some as a further effort to consolidate his power.
item.description: Critics of Venezuela’s government say the arrests of the six executives are a reflection of the country’s increasingly ruthless politics.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Russia, Turkey and Iran Propose Conference on Postwar Syria’s Future
item.media:description: From left, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey in Sochi, Russia, on Wednesday.
item.description: The conference, to be held in the Russian resort of Sochi, reflected Russia’s increased influence in shaping the outcome of the Syria war.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: Border Homes, in Jerusalem but Not, Face an Existential Deadline
item.media:description: For years, a Jerusalem neighborhood has thrived outside the barrier wall, largely ignored by the city. Now the city plans to demolish these apartment buildings, upsetting residents.
item.media:credit: Fadi Arouri for The New York Times
item.description: The quarter’s quirky status made it a boomtown, but a planned road threatens todrive people out of their homes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Thanksgiving, Net Neutrality, Ratko Mladic: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and DAVID SCULL

item.title: Letter 35: Outtakes From Manus Island
item.media:description: Asylum seekers smuggling food and medicine into the Manus Island detention center.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: This week’s Australia newsletter includes additional photography and stories from Manus, and a dash of American Thanksgiving.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: At UEFA, Mounting Concern About A.C. Milan’s Murky Finances
item.media:description: Milan's chief executive, Marco Fassone, with the team's coach, Vincenzo Montella, and the team director David Han Li before a match on Saturday. Milan is trying to persuade European soccer's governing body, UEFA, to grant it a waiver from so-called financial fair play rules.
item.description: UEFA will decide early next month whether A.C. Milan, a seven-time European champion, has the financial resources to re-enter its continental championships should it play its way back in.
item.dc:creator: TARIQ PANJA

item.title: Yemen’s War Is a Tragedy. Is It Also a Crime?
item.media:description: A malnourished Yemeni child getting treatment at a hospital in the port city of Al Hudaydah on Nov. 5.
item.description: Experts say the parties waging war in Yemen may be carrying out crimes against humanity. But what does that actually mean?
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Rival Factions Battle for Control in Eastern Ukraine
item.media:description: Armed men blocked access to government buildings in Luhansk, in eastern Ukraine, on Wednesday after the interior minister refused to step down.
item.description: With armored vehicles on streets, civilians fled a showdown between rival Moscow-backed political leaders in the breakaway Luhansk region.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW LUXMOORE

item.title: North Korea Accuses Trump of a ‘Serious Provocation’
item.media:description: President Trump before a cabinet meeting on Monday, the day he restored North Korea to Washington’s list of terrorism-sponsoring states. On Wednesday, Pyongyang called that move a “serious provocation.”
item.description: North Korea criticizes President Trump’s re-designation of it as a state sponsor of terrorism and vows to keep up its nuclear and missile programs.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: 7 In-Depth Articles About Ratko Mladic
item.media:description: General Mladic, center, observing the positions of Bosnian government forces in Gorazde, eastern Bosnia, in 1994.
item.description: The Bosnian Serb former general, convicted of war crimes for the slaughter of Bosnian Muslims, has shaped the region’s image in war and in peace.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia

item.title: U.K. Finance Minister Seeks to Placate Angry Young Voters
item.media:description: Philip Hammond on Wednesday at 11 Downing Street, the traditional address of Britain’s chancellor of the Exchequer, before presenting his budget blueprint to Parliament.
item.description: With Brexit looming large, more-affordable housing featured prominently as Philip Hammond presented his budget to Parliament.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Emmerson Mnangagwa, Mugabe Ex-Deputy, Will Be Sworn In as Zimbabwe’s President
item.media:description: Emmerson Mnangagwa, who is to be sworn in as Zimbabwe’s next president on Friday, greeted supporters gathered outside the governing party’s headquarters in Harare, Zimbabwe, on Wednesday.
item.description: Mr. Mnangagwa’s ascension to the post long held by Robert Mugabe will cap a military-led campaign that his allies have tried to coat with a veneer of legality.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Saad Hariri Steps Back From Resignation in Lebanon
item.media:description: Saad Hariri attended a military parade in Beirut, Lebanon, on Wednesday to celebrate the country’s Independence Day.
item.description: The prime minister caused a shock when he appeared in Saudi Arabia and vowed to quit. He now says he will stay in his post to allow for political dialogue.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Mladic Conviction Closes Dark Chapter in Europe, but New Era of Uncertainty Looms
item.media:description: Many in Srebrenica, Bosnia and Herzegovina, watching a live broadcast of the trial cheered when the verdict was announced on Wednesday.
item.description: Ratko Mladic received a life sentence for his role in one of the worst atrocities in 20th-century Europe. But nationalist passions are once again on the rise.
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS, ALAN COWELL and BARBARA SURK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia
